settings.text: A urinary tract infection (UTI) can be diagnosed in a number of different ways. The most typical method involves collecting a urine sample and sending it to a lab for analysis. A dipstick test can also be used by a medical professional to find bacteria and white blood cells in urine. To rule out alternative conditions, imaging tests like an ultrasound or CT scan may occasionally be required. The purpose of this article is to provide information to Welzo users about UTI.

An intense, enduring urge to urinate, Experiencing burning while urinating, Pelvic discomfort in womenurine that is cloudy or bloody, Urine with a strong smell, in severe cases, a fever or chills. Consult with a healthcare professional as soon as you can if you suspect a UTI. A UTI can cause serious complications, like kidney damage, if it is not treated.

Antibiotics are typically used to treat UTIs.Even if your symptoms go away, it is crucial to finish the entire antibiotic course.This will assist in ensuring that the infection is completely eradicated.Additionally, fluid intake and frequent urination can lessen symptoms and hasten recovery.Urinary tract infections are fairly common, but if they aren't treated right away, they can be painful and lead to other issues.Consult your healthcare provider for a diagnosis and treatment if you believe you may have a UTI.

settings.heading: How to prevent Urinary Tract Infections

settings.text: Your doctor might suggest a preventive antibiotic if you are prone to UTIs. This is typically taken after sexual activity or once daily. People who have weakened immune systems or certain medical conditions like diabetes may be more likely to get UTIs and may need to take preventive antibiotics for a long time.
